Updated: June 2, 2024 @ 5:12 am COFFEE WITH A COP - From left, Gettysburg Police Officers Kevin Bigler and Brian Weikert speak with borough resident Michael Gelner during Wednesday\'s "Coffee with a Cop" event at McDonald\'s on Steinwehr Avenue. In the background, Police Chief Joe Dougherty speaks with local McDonald\'s owner Emmett Patterson. (Jim Hale/Gettysburg Times) Coffee with a Cop serves up a weekly opportunity for the public to meet informally with Gettysburg Borough Police Department officers. This week\'s event came with a twist. Coffee with a Cop normally takes place Tuesdays at 9 a.m. at McDonald\'s, 517 Steinwehr Ave., but this week\'s event was delayed until Wednesday to coincide with National Coffee with a Cop Day. Genny Reaver, a resident of the borough for 52 years, said she attended the event in order to thank officers for their work. "They\'re worth it. They protect us every day," she said. Most people never interact with a police officer except when there is "a crisis or problem," and citizens may feel reluctant to interrupt officers who are on duty, Police Chief Joe Dougherty said. By contrast, he said, Coffee with a Cop offers an opportunity to meet in a "non-stressful" atmosphere. The events help the public "know what we do" and provide a "direct connection" that "lets us see each other as human beings," Dougherty said. A core group of four or five citizens have attended many of the sessions, which also draw in other patrons of the restaurant, he said. Local McDonald\'s owner Emmett Patterson approached Dougherty with the idea for the events, which began about 16 months ago, Dougherty said. "The community needs to have contact with the police in a less stressful situation, and this is perfect," Patterson said Wednesday at the event. "It\'s also a way to say thank you to our police officers," he said. "Community involvement" is an important goal for McDonald\'s, just as it is for police officers, McDonald\'s Area Supervisor Rance Strasbaugh said. Borough resident Michael Gelner said he attended because of a general interest in government and "to get to know the officers more." Coffee with a Cop offers a chance to do the latter in "a little more relaxed atmosphere," he said. Officers\' participation in the events show the department is "not defensive, and open to meeting people and hearing their concerns," Gelner said. "It\'s important to have a dialogue" other than "during a tense time," Michael\'s wife Kathy Gelner said. "The more you know each other, the better it is," she said. Coffee with a Cop has been popular with officers as well as citizens, Dougherty said. The relaxed setting lets citizens ask questions and raise neighborhood issues they would be reluctant to call 911 about, said Sgt. Harald Pruy, one of several officers present Wednesday. Officer Chris Evans presented a coloring book and crayons to a young restaurant patron. "I like to color hard," said Jebb Cain, 3, who was visiting Gettysburg with his parents, Deanna and Matt Cain of New Martinsville, W. Va. "I\'m an art teacher. We color a lot," Deanna said. Jebb nodded when asked whether he liked meeting the officer. Evans said Wednesday\'s event was his third Coffee with a Cop. The events provide a chance "to get the know the community a little bit," which is especially valuable for someone like himself who joined the department only recently, he said. It\'s also valuable for the public to see that the department is "approachable," Evans said. Bev Frey, a field representative for state Sen. Richard Alloway, R-33, also attended the event. But this year, she said she received a scholarship to attend the four-day boot camp, which consisted of classroom learning each morning, and chocolate-making labs in the afternoons. “They covered a lot in a few days,” she said, holding up a huge binder of course work from the program that was held at Fascia’s Chocolates, a small family business located for years in Waterbury, Conn. The goal for her, Mortensen said, was to “come back to Char-Val and feel confident. And take my family’s business to the next level that I know it’s capable of.” During the boot camp, she said students were tight about tempering chocolate, a process of brining the chocolate to a high heat, and back down again so it can be worked with property. When temperated properly, the chocolate will display a shiny coating. “There’s a whole science behind it,” Mortensen said, noting that the course helped build on what she has learned over the past few years at Char-Val. “We’ve been doing it an old-fashioned way, so it was neat to learn a newer way.” She said she also learned techniques to fine-tune peanut butter meltaways, and how to trouble-shoot other issues. The four-day course culminated in a big test at the end, with Mortensen earning a certificate of completion. “It wasn’t just going up there to play with chocolate,” she said, adding that the instructors for the boot camp are some of the best chocolatiers in the industry. The boot camp lessons ranged from the process of growing and harvesting cocoa beans, to the artistry involved in chocolate making. “I saw the whole range from beginning to advanced,” she said. Mortensen said that what was learned at the program will help continue to take Char-Val in new directions, and continue the process of adding new product’s to the local candy company’s line. “I want to be prepared for growth because we are definitely headed in that direction,” she said. Back at Char-Val, Mortensen said she serves in a managerial and ownership roll, enjoying the time she has to work with her grandfather, mother and aunt. “It’s very special to have us all together here,” she said. Especially right now, one of the busiest times of year as the candy maker gears up for the Easter season, which traditionally marks the seasonal closing of the local business. “It’s really all-hands-on-deck right now,” she said, noting that the holiday rush culminates with a three-day Easter sale Thursday through Saturday, April 14-16, that will see crowds of chocolate-lovers pour in to get all the holiday goodies and other candies to stock up until Char-Val reopens at the end of summer. “We’re still very much seasonal,” she said, adding that there still is plenty of work to be done during the summer.
